{{Short description|Italian telecommunications company}} {{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]; requested at [[WP:RfPP]]|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = TIM S.p.A. | logo = GRUPPO TIM.svg | logo_size = | image = Telecom Italia - Sede Corso Italia.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = TIM Group's headquarters in Rome, Italy | former_name = Telecom Italia S.p.A. (1994-2016) | type = [[Public company|Public]] [[S.p.A.]] | traded_as = {{ISE|IT0003497168|TIT}} | hq_location_city = [[Rome]], [[Milan]] and [[Naples]] | hq_location_country = Italy | area_served = [[Italy]] | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|Luigi Gubitosi ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])|[[Salvatore Rossi]] ([[Chairman of the board|Chairman]]){{cite web|url=https://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/it/about-us/organizational-chart/salvatore-rossi-presidente-telecom-italia.html |title=Salvatore Rossi - Presidente Telecom Italia | Gruppo TIM |publisher=Telecomitalia.com |access-date=2019-11-22}}}} | ISIN = IT0003497168 | industry = [[Telecommunications industry|Telecommunications]] | products = {{Unbulleted list|[[Fixed telephony]]|[[Public telephony]]|[[Mobile telephony]]|[[Broadband Internet]]|[[IT Services]]|[[Telecommunications network|Networking Solutions]]|[[Digital television]]}} | revenue = {{decrease}} {{€|15.32 billion|link=yes}} (2021){{cite web |url= https://www.gruppotim.it/content/dam/gt/investitori/doc---report-finanziari/2021/Annual-report-2021.pdf|title=Annual report |date=2021 |website= www.telecomitalia.com|access-date=2022-04-03}} | net_income = {{decrease}} {{€|−8.40 billion}} (2021) | assets = {{decrease}} {{€|69.19 billion}} (2021) | equity = {{decrease}} {{€|17.41 billion}} (2021) | num_employees = {{decrease}} 51,929 (end 2021) | predecessor = [[SIP (company)|SIP]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1994|07|27|df=y}} | founder = [[Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale|IRI]] | subsid = {{Unbulleted list|[[Telecom Italia Mobile|TIM]] (100%)|[[Telecom Italia Finance]] (100%)|[[TIM Brasil]] (0.0001%)|[[Telecom Italia San Marino]] (100%)|[[TIMvision]] (100%)|[[Telecom Italia Media]] (71.6909%)|[[Telecom Italia Trust Technologies]] (100%)|[[Telsy]] (100%)|[[Flash Fiber]] (80%)|[[Olivetti]] (100%)|[[Infrastrutture Wireless Italiane|INWIT]] (37.5%)|[[Telecom Italia Sparkle]] (100%)}} | owners = [[Vivendi]] (23.75%)
[[Cassa Depositi e Prestiti]] (9.81%){{cite web|url=https://www.gruppotim.it/en/investors/shares/shareholders.html|title=TIM Group's Shareholders|website=www.gruppotim.it|access-date=2022-03-03}} | parent = | website = {{URL|https://www.gruppotim.it/en.html|www.gruppotim.it}} }} '''TIM [[S.p.A.]]''' (formerly '''Telecom Italia S.p.A.'''),{{Cite web |date= |title=Legal notes {{!}} TIM Group |url=https://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/footer/Note-legali.html |access-date=2019-11-09 |website=www.telecomitalia.com}} commonly known as '''TIM Group''', is an Italian [[telecommunications company]] with [[headquarters]] in [[Rome]], [[Milan]], and [[Naples]] (with the [[Telecom Italia Tower (Naples)|Telecom Italia Tower]]), which provides [[fixed telephony]] and [[DSL]] data [[Service (economics)|services]].{{Cite web |date= |title=Profile {{!}} TIM Group |url=https://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/about-us/profile.html |access-date=2019-11-09 |website=www.telecomitalia.com}} It is the largest Italian telecommunications services provider in revenues and subscribers. It was founded in 1994 by the [[Mergers and acquisitions|merger]] of several [[State-owned enterprise|state-owned]] telecommunications companies, the most prominent of which was [[SIP (company)|SIP]], the former state monopoly telephone operator in Italy.{{Cite web |date= |title=1980s – 1990s {{!}} TIM Group |url=https://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/about-us/history/80s-90s.html |access-date=2019-11-09 |website=www.telecomitalia.com}}{{Cite web |date= |title=Business history {{!}} archiviostorico.telecomitalia.com |url=https://archiviostorico.telecomitalia.com/italia-al-telefono-oltre/business-history |access-date=2017-06-28 |website=archiviostorico.telecomitalia.com}} The [[company]]'s stock is traded in the [[Borsa Italiana]]. Since 2017, the Italian State exercises on TIM the "Golden Power", which allows the government to take a number of actions when the strategic interests of the country are concerned. TIM Group has also a [[subsidiary]] in [[Brazil]], known as [[TIM Brasil]], with 72.6 million customers.{{cite web |author=Scott Bicheno |date=January 14, 2016 |title=Telecom Italia formally unifies brands under TIM name |url=http://telecoms.com/461962/telecom-italia-formally-unifies-brands-under-tim-name/ |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=telecoms.com}} The brand covers over 114 million customers worldwide.{{cite web |title=Breaking Barriers to Transform TIM's Brand and Business |url=http://interbrand.com/work/breaking-barriers-to-transform-tim-brand-and-business/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191021064809/https://www.interbrand.com/work/breaking-barriers-to-transform-tim-brand-and-business/ |archive-date=21 October 2019 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |publisher=Interbrand}} ==History== ===1925–1964: STIPEL and early mandatory phone tax=== In 1925, the [[Italy|Italian]] [[Telephone network|phone network]] was reorganised by the [[Mussolini government|Benito Mussolini cabinet]] and the [[company]] [[STIPEL]] was established in the same year. The original core of Telecom Italia included four companies: [[TIMO]], [[TE.TI.]], [[TELVE]] and [[SET (company)|SET]]. Each of them operated in a specific geographical area.{{cite web|url=http://www.forumti.it/fti/downloads/Summary%20(in%20english).pdf?ref=search|title=Economics and politics of telecommunications}} ===1964–1994: SIP=== {{Main|SIP (company)}} In 1964, [[Società Idroelettrica Piemontese]] (SIP), a former [[energy company]] founded in 1918, ceased producing [[energy]] and [[Mergers and acquisitions|acquired]] all of the Italian [[Telephone company|telephone companies]], becoming [[Società Italiana per l'Esercizio Telefonico]] (SIP). It was run by the [[Ministry of Economy and Finance (Italy)|Italian Ministry of Finance]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2022}} SIP was a [[state monopoly]] from 1964 to 1996 and Italian people had to pay the "Canone Telecom" (a [[Fixed-line|line]] rental charge of about €120 per year, plus [[Electronic hardware|hardware]] rental and other minor costs) in order to have a [[Fixed phone|phone]] at home. ===1994–2005: Telecom Italia, Telecom Italia Mobile and DSL services=== ''Telecom Italia S.p.A.'' was officially created on 27 July 1994 by the [[merger]] of several [[Telecommunications company|telecommunications companies]] among which SIP, [[IRITEL]], [[Italcable]], [[Telespazio]] and [[SIRM]] (companies owned by [[STET – Società Finanziaria Telefonica|STET]]).{{Cite web|url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/corporate/about-us/history/80s-90s.html|title=Telecom Italia history on official site}}{{cite web |url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1994/marzo/18/nasce_Telecom_Italia_co_0_94031816349.shtml |title=nasce Telecom Italia |website=Corriere.it |language=it |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120803190924/http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1994/marzo/18/nasce_Telecom_Italia_co_0_94031816349.shtml |archive-date=2012-08-03}} This was due to a reorganization plan for the [[Telecommunications industry|telecommunications sector]] presented by [[Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale|IRI]] to the Minister of Finance. In 1995, the [[mobile telephony]] [[Division (business)|division]] was spun off as [[Telecom Italia Mobile]] (TIM), while Telecom Italia would take care of [[Fixed telephony|fixed]] and [[public telephony]] and [[Network infrastructure|network infrastructures]]. Interbusiness, Italy's largest [[Internet]] [[Telecommunications network|network]], was created and in the same period with [[Tin.it|Telecom Italia Net]] (Tin.it) and the first [[Internet Service Provider|ISPs]], [[Internet access]] became a reality in Italy.{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1995/febbraio/22/TELECOM_ITALIA_Interbusiness_con_Internet_co_8_9502221529.shtml|title=Archivio Corriere della Sera|website=archiviostorico.corriere.it}} In 1996, TIM introduced a new [[Rechargeable calling card|prepaid rechargeable phone card]]{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-q6GrtjFqYkC&pg=PA45|title=The economics of mobile telecommunications page 45 reference #50}} ([[GSM]]), and one year later launched [[Short Messaging Service|short messaging service]] (SMS) capability. In 1997, under the [[chairmanship]] of [[Guido Rossi (jurist)|Guido Rossi]], Telecom Italia was [[Privatization|privatised]] and was transformed into a large [[multimedia]] group. By 2001, the company was in debt and was acquired by [[Marco Tronchetti Provera]]. The following year, the group released its [[DSL]] Flat service in Italy, [[Alice ADSL]], with a download speed of 32 kbit/s and an upload speed of 8 kbit/s for €40/month plus a monthly based tax of €14.57, the "Canone Telecom", besides the mandatory monthly [[Bill (payment)|bills]] for home [[Telephone number|telephone numbers]] (a home telephone number was required for [[ADSL]] service). [[Telecom Italia Media]], the group's multimedia company, was formed in 2003 from [[SEAT Pagine Gialle]], focussing its [[business]] on the [[Television industry|television sector]] with [[La7]] and [[MTV (Italy)|MTV]] [[Television channel|channels]].{{cite web|url=http://www.telecomitaliamedia.it/et/content/profile|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713155259/http://www.telecomitaliamedia.it/et/content/profile|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-07-13|title=Telecom Italia Media official site}} After the reorganization of [[Publishing industry|editorial]] activities, in 2005 Telecom Italia acquired Tin.it and [[Virgilio.it|Virgilio]] from Telecom Italia Media.{{cite web|url=http://archivio-radiocor.ilsole24ore.com/articolo-433346/telecom-acquista-virgilio-tin-it/|title=News archive on IlSole24ore}} The Telecom Italia Group also operates in [[South America]]; in [[Brazil]] as [[TIM Brasil]], and in [[Argentina]] and [[Paraguay]] with [[Telecom Argentina]]. TIM Brasil has its local [[headquarters]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bnamericas.com/company-profile/en/tim-participacoes-sa-tim-participacoes?ref=search|title=TIM Participações S.A. (TIM Participações) - BNamericas}} Telecom Italia also had a 50% share in the [[Bolivia|Bolivian]] telecommunications company [[Entel (Bolivia)|Entel]] until its share was nationalised by the [[Bolivian government]] in 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=217331&id_seccion=5 |title=Bolivia acepta arbitraje por nacionalización de una telefónica |publisher=El Comercio |date=August 27, 2008 |language=es |access-date=2010-04-13}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{Cite news|date=2008-05-01|title=UPDATE 1-Bolivia announces takeover of Telecom Italia unit|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/entel-bolivia-idUSN0121819820080501|access-date=2020-09-17}} ===2005–2014: Telecom Italia acquired by Telefónica=== Telecom Italia reported mounting debts in 2005, and, one year later, [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] Marco Tronchetti Provera resigned.{{cite web|url=https://www.pirelli.com/mediaObject/corporate/documents/en/media/pirelli_telecom/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007/original/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007.pdf?ref=search|title=Pirelli as manager and investor in Telecom Italia (2001-2007)|access-date=24 August 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908100217/https://www.pirelli.com/mediaObject/corporate/documents/en/media/pirelli_telecom/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007/original/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007.pdf?ref=search|archive-date=8 September 2015|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}} In 2007 the company was bought by Telco, a consortium of [[Telefónica]] and several [[Italian banks]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/29/technology/29cnd-telecom.html|title=Telefónica Gets Controlling Stake in Telecom Italia|first1=Victoria|last1=Burnett|first2=Peter|last2=Kiefer|newspaper=The New York Times |date=29 April 2007}} Telefónica owned 46% of Telco, the [[holding company]] that controlled 22% of Telecom Italia. In late 2013, Telefónica announced its intention to acquire the entirety of Telco by January 2014, potentially becoming Telecom Italia's largest [[shareholder]].{{Cite news|last=Mesco|first=Gabriele Lamonica And Manuela|date=2013-09-23|title=Telefónica in Talks to Become Majority Stakeholder in Telecom Italia's Holding Company|language=en-US|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702303759604579093060864026116.html|access-date=2021-04-02|issn=0099-9660}}{{Cite web|last=Emsden|first=Christopher|title=Telefonica to take control of Italy's Telco|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/telefonica-to-take-control-of-italys-telco-2013-09-24|access-date=2021-04-02|website=MarketWatch|language=en-US}} The plan, however, is being challenged by the Brazilian competition authority since Telefónica and Telecom Italia, with [[Vivo (telecommunications)|Vivo]] and TIM respectively, are the two largest telephone companies competing in Brazil. ===2015–present: Rebrand=== In 2015, the company started a [[rebranding]] process towards the unified TIM [[brand]], which would no longer be used only to identify mobile telephony offers but also for fixed telephony ones, abandoning the Telecom Italia brand.{{cite web|url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/economico-finanziario/2015/2015-2017-strategic-plan-approved.html|title=Telecom Italia Group: 2015–2017 strategic plan approved, cumulative investments planned totalling around 14.5 billion euros over the three year period|access-date=2015-04-02|work=Telecom Italia}}{{Cite web |date= |title=Telecom Italia diventa TIM |url=http://in.tim.it/telecom-italia-diventa-tim/ |access-date=2015-08-13 |website=in.tim.it |language=it}}{{Cite web |date= |title=Telecom Italia diventa TIM - La Nuova TIM |url=http://in.tim.it/la-nuova-tim/ |access-date=2015-08-13 |website=in.tim.it |language=it}}{{Cite web |date= |title=Nuovo sito TIM Telecom italia |url=http://www.tim.it/nuovo-sito-TIM-Telecom-italia |access-date=2015-08-13 |website=www.tim.it |language=it}} In the same year, the [[board of directors]] approved the new company's division, [[Infrastrutture Wireless Italiane]] (INWIT) which operates 11,500 [[Cell site|wireless towers]].{{cite news |title=Telecom Italia gets OK for towers IPO, values it at €2.34B |url=http://seekingalpha.com/news/2564296-telecom-italia-gets-ok-for-towers-ipo-values-it-at-2_34b |date=5 June 2015 |work=Seeking Alpha |author=Aycock, Jason }}{{cite news |title=Telecom Italia gets regulatory OK for €1bn towers IPO |author=Lennighan, Mary |date=5 June 2015 |work=Total Telecom |url=http://www.totaltele.com/view.aspx?ID=490171 }} It was revealed in October 2015 that shareholders [[Vivendi]] would raise their stakes further in the company from its current level of 15.49%.{{cite web|title=Exclusive: Vivendi moves to raise Telecom Italia stake to around 19 percent - sources|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/01/us-telecomitalia-vivendi-exclusive-idUSKCN0RV5Q020151001|website=Reuters|date=1 October 2015|access-date=2 July 2017|archive-date=2 December 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181202064808/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-telecomitalia-vivendi-exclusive/exclusive-vivendi-moves-to-raise-telecom-italia-stake-to-around-19-percent-sources-idUSKCN0RV5Q020151001|url-status=dead}} As of May 2017, Vivendi owns 24.6% of the company with Vivendi's CEO [[Arnaud de Puyfontaine]] becoming [[executive chairman]] of Telecom Italia.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-telecomitalia-vivendi-chairman/telecom-italia-names-vivendi-ceo-de-puyfontaine-as-chairman-source-idUSKBN18S5LC|title=Telecom Italia appoints Vivendi's CEO as chairman|date=1 June 2017|newspaper=Reuters}} Amos Genish is the new CEO since 28 September 2017 and he has been criticized to have fired 4500 Telecom Italia employees in June 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.it/2018/05/17/tim-al-via-cassa-integrazione-per-3-4mila-persone_a_23436776/|title=Tim, scatta la cassa integrazione: in un anno gli esuberi arriveranno a 4.500|date=17 May 2018|website=L'HuffPost}} He has been substituted by Luigi Gubitosi that became the new CEO on 18 November 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.corriere.it/economia/18_novembre_18/chi-gubitosi-l-uomo-operazioni-difficili-4b4d6778-eb25-11e8-a3a7-d3b748828557.shtml|title=Chi è Gubitosi, l'uomo delle operazioni difficili|first=Redazione|last=Economia|date=18 November 2018|website=Corriere della Sera}} In 2016, following the rebranding that led to the adoption of the single TIM brand, the [[parent company]] also decided to change its identity. The company name of Telecom Italia S.p.A. it was in fact changed to ''TIM S.p.A.'', however still maintaining the previous name on some occasions.{{Cite web |date= |title=Telecom Italia shareholders' meeting held: all items on the agenda approved {{!}} Telecom Italia Group |url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/economico-finanziario/2016/Telecom-Italia-shareholders-meeting-2016-05-25.html |access-date=2016-05-29 |website=www.telecomitalia.com}} ===Main shareholders=== The main [[Shareholder|shareholders]] of TIM Group on 25 November 2022 are:{{cite web |title=Significant Shareholdings |url=https://www.gruppotim.it/en/investors/shares/significant_shareholdings.html |website=.gruppotim.it |publisher=.gruppotim.it |access-date=19 April 2023}}{{cite web |title=Telecom Italia |url=https://www.borsaitaliana.it/borsa/azioni/profilo-societa-dettaglio.html?isin=IT0003497168&lang=it |website=borsaitaliana.it |publisher=borsaitaliana.it |access-date=19 April 2023}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Rank !! Name !! Percentage !! Substantial shareholders |- | 1 || [[Vivendi|Vivendi SE]] ([[France]])|| 23.746% || |- | 2 || [[Cassa Depositi e Prestiti|Cassa Depositi e Prestiti S.p.A.]] ([[Italy]])|| 9.810% || |- | 3 || Telecom Italia S.p.A. || 0.756% || |} ==Legal problems== ===Telecom Italia Mobile illegal charging money for "free" Internet providing renewals=== [[Telecom Italia Mobile]] illegally charged money for Internet providing renew subscriptions for 5 years to its customers during the "free" subscription renewals.{{cite web|url=https://www.latecnosfera.com/2013/05/ecco-come-tim-frega-3-o-4-euro-ai-suoi.html|title=Ecco come Tim frega 4 euro al rinnovo delle promozioni - Tecnosfera|date=30 May 2013}} ===Fraud in Brazilian prepaid mobile lines=== On 8 August 2012, [[TIM Brasil]] became involved in a massive scandal in Brazilian news after the release of report by the Brazilian National Telecommunications Agency Anatel.{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/parana/noticia/2012/08/tim-derruba-os-sinais-de-clientes-de-forma-proposital-aponta-relatorio.html |title=G1 – TIM derruba os sinais de clientes de forma proposital, aponta relatório – notícias em Paraná |date=7 August 2012 |publisher=G1.globo.com |access-date=2012-08-17}} The report points that on TIM's prepaid voice plan (24.7% market share), called "Infinity" (in which the user pays roughly US$0.12 for each unlimited time call), the calls were intentionally dropped by the company, forcing the customers to make (and pay for) new calls to keep talking. In just one day, 8.1 million calls were dropped and the total profit was approximately $2 million. Upon release of the report, the Public Ministry of the Paraná State filed a lawsuit against TIM asking that it stop selling new mobile lines in Brasil and pay a multimillion-dollar fine for the damages against consumers.{{cite web|url= http://g1.globo.com/parana/noticia/2012/08/ministerio-publico-pede-suspensao-de-venda-de-chips-da-tim-no-parana.html |title= G1 – Ministério Público pede a suspensão de venda de chips da TIM no Paraná – notícias em Paraná |date= 6 August 2012 |publisher= G1.globo.com |access-date= 2012-08-17 }} ==Operations== The Telecom Italia Group provides phone landline services and mobile services in Italy, GSM mobile phone services in Italy and Brazil through its [[Telecom Italia Mobile|TIM]] and [[TIM Brasil]] [[Subsidiary|subsidiaries]], and [[DSL]] Internet and telephony services in Italy and [[San Marino]] (through [[Telecom Italia San Marino]]). It also operates in international [[Telecommunications service|telecommunications services]] for other operators and corporations, through its subsidiary [[Telecom Italia Sparkle]]. In 2013, the total amount of the company's debt was about 26 billion €.{{cite web|url=http://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2014/03/25/telecom-patuano-prepara-la-guerra-a-fossati-in-ballo-ce-uno-stipendio-da-1-milione/926469/|title=Telecom, Patuano prepara la guerra a Fossati. In ballo c'è uno stipendio da 1 milione - Il Fatto Quotidiano|author=Costanza Iotti|work=Il Fatto Quotidiano|date=25 March 2014 |access-date=2015-04-21}} Telecom Italia has 66,025 employees. Telecom Italia also controls [[Olivetti]], a manufacturer of computer peripherals and mobile phones. On March 31, 2014, Telecom Italia led both the direct fixed access lines market with a 62% share, and the mobile [[postpaid]] segment with a 45% market share. In the mobile "[[prepaid mobile phone|prepaid]]" segment Telecom Italia owned a 31.5% market share together with [[Vodafone]].{{cite web|url=http://www.agcom.it/documents/10179/1734740/Allegato+24-7-2014/d7ff11cd-3f3e-4742-b121-75f4e9ae8d34?version=1.0|title=Osservatorio Trimestrale sulle Telecomunicazioni |publisher=Agcom.it}} After the merger of [[WIND (Italy)|Wind]] and [[3 Italy]], approved on August 6, 2015, Telecom Italia is now the country's second largest carrier with 30 million customers, followed by [[Vodafone Italy|Vodafone]] with 25 million customers.{{cite web|url=http://www.pyramidresearch.com/about-us/media-center/press-releases/the-merger-wind-3-italia-may-unlock-convergence-opportunities/?ref=search|title=Pyramid Research - The merger Wind-3 Italia may unlock convergence opportunities|website=www.pyramidresearch.com}} Telecom Italia has preserved its leadership on the direct fixed access lines market and the mobile postpaid segment.{{cite web|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/finanza-e-mercati/2015-08-06/tlc-siglate-nozze-wind-e-3-italia-145750.shtml?uuid=ACn8Hwd?ref=search|title=Tlc, nozze tra Wind e 3 Italia. Fusione da 6,4 mld per il nuovo leader del mercato mobile}} ===High Debt Issue=== Telecom Italia S.p.A. deals with a total debt of 27 billion Euro as of the end of 2019. Moody rated the debt with a B1 grade negative outlook in 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-assigns-Ba1-to-Telecom-Italias-Unsecured-Equity-Linked-Bonds--PR_321493|title=Moody's assigns Ba1 to Telecom Italia's Unsecured Equity-Linked Bonds; negative outlook|date=25 March 2015|website=Moodys.com}} ==Environmental practices and initiatives== In 2002, Telecom Italia subscribed to the [[United Nations]] [[Corporate social responsibility|corporate responsibility]] initiative [[The Global Compact|Global Compact]].{{cite journal |url=http://www.telecomitalia.it/content/dam/telecomitalia/en/archive/documents/sustainability/sustainability_reports/2009/Bilancio_sostenibilita_ENG_2009.pdf |title=Sustainability Report 2009 |access-date=27 July 2010 |journal=Telecom Italia |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705121258/http://www.telecomitalia.it/content/dam/telecomitalia/en/archive/documents/sustainability/sustainability_reports/2009/Bilancio_sostenibilita_ENG_2009.pdf |archive-date=5 July 2010}} It is also member of a number of stock market indexes which include companies focused on corporate social responsibility, including the [[Dow Jones Sustainability Index]]es and those administered by [[FTSE Group]]'s [[FTSE4Good]]. Its part-owned Brazilian subsidiary, [[TIM Brasil]], is listed in the [[BM&F Bovespa|Bovespa]]'s ISE (Índice de Sustentabilidade Empresarial) index.{{cite web |url=http://ri.tim.com.br/Show.aspx?IdMateria=2qNyWOWlMW4SUKaEph3e1Q== |title=Notice Bovespa ISE |access-date=29 April 2013 |work=TIM Participações S.A. |archive-url=https://archive.today/2013.06.16-004043/http://ri.tim.com.br/Show.aspx?IdMateria=2qNyWOWlMW4SUKaEph3e1Q== |archive-date=16 June 2013}} Telecom Italia promotes a [[sustainability]] strategy including both environmental and social issues: in June 2014 it signed an agreement with [[A2A]] to buy energy only from [[renewable sources]].{{cite news |url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/istituzionale/2014/06-23.html?ref=search |title=Telecom Italia signs an agreement with A2A to buy energy only from renewable sources |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924114706/http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/istituzionale/2014/06-23.html?ref=search |archive-date=24 September 2015 |date=23 June 2014 |access-date=16 May 2022 |work=Telecom Italia}} == Logo history == File:Logo Telecom Italia (1994-2003).svg|1994-2003 File:Logo Telecom Italia contentMetadata.text: TIM S.p.A. (formerly Telecom Italia S.p.A.), commonly known as TIM Group, is an Italian telecommunications company with headquarters in Rome, Milan, and Naples (with the Telecom Italia Tower), which provides fixed telephony and DSL data services. It is the largest Italian telecommunications services provider in revenues and subscribers. It was founded in 1994 by the merger of several state-owned telecommunications companies, the most prominent of which was SIP, the former state monopoly telephone operator in Italy. The company's stock is traded in the Borsa Italiana. Since 2017, the Italian State exercises on TIM the "Golden Power", which allows the government to take a number of actions when the strategic interests of the country are concerned. TIM Group has also a subsidiary in Brazil, known as TIM Brasil, with 72.6 million customers. The brand covers over 114 million customers worldwide. In 1925, the Italian phone network was reorganised by the Benito Mussolini cabinet and the company STIPEL was established in the same year. The original core of Telecom Italia included four companies: TIMO, TE.TI., TELVE and SET. Each of them operated in a specific geographical area. In 1964, Società Idroelettrica Piemontese (SIP), a former energy company founded in 1918, ceased producing energy and acquired all of the Italian telephone companies, becoming Società Italiana per l'Esercizio Telefonico (SIP). It was run by the Italian Ministry of Finance.[citation needed] SIP was a state monopoly from 1964 to 1996 and Italian people had to pay the "Canone Telecom" (a line rental charge of about €120 per year, plus hardware rental and other minor costs) in order to have a phone at home. Telecom Italia S.p.A. was officially created on 27 July 1994 by the merger of several telecommunications companies among which SIP, IRITEL, Italcable, Telespazio and SIRM (companies owned by STET). This was due to a reorganization plan for the telecommunications sector presented by IRI to the Minister of Finance. In 1995, the mobile telephony division was spun off as Telecom Italia Mobile (TIM), while Telecom Italia would take care of fixed and public telephony and network infrastructures. Interbusiness, Italy's largest Internet network, was created and in the same period with Telecom Italia Net (Tin.it) and the first ISPs, Internet access became a reality in Italy. In 1996, TIM introduced a new prepaid rechargeable phone card (GSM), and one year later launched short messaging service (SMS) capability. In 1997, under the chairmanship of Guido Rossi, Telecom Italia was privatised and was transformed into a large multimedia group. By 2001, the company was in debt and was acquired by Marco Tronchetti Provera. The following year, the group released its DSL Flat service in Italy, Alice ADSL, with a download speed of 32 kbit/s and an upload speed of 8 kbit/s for €40/month plus a monthly based tax of €14.57, the "Canone Telecom", besides the mandatory monthly bills for home telephone numbers (a home telephone number was required for ADSL service). Telecom Italia Media, the group's multimedia company, was formed in 2003 from SEAT Pagine Gialle, focussing its business on the television sector with La7 and MTV channels. After the reorganization of editorial activities, in 2005 Telecom Italia acquired Tin.it and Virgilio from Telecom Italia Media. The Telecom Italia Group also operates in South America; in Brazil as TIM Brasil, and in Argentina and Paraguay with Telecom Argentina. TIM Brasil has its local headquarters in Rio de Janeiro. Telecom Italia also had a 50% share in the Bolivian telecommunications company Entel until its share was nationalised by the Bolivian government in 2008. Telecom Italia reported mounting debts in 2005, and, one year later, CEO Marco Tronchetti Provera resigned. In 2007 the company was bought by Telco, a consortium of Telefónica and several Italian banks. Telefónica owned 46% of Telco, the holding company that controlled 22% of Telecom Italia. In late 2013, Telefónica announced its intention to acquire the entirety of Telco by January 2014, potentially becoming Telecom Italia's largest shareholder. The plan, however, is being challenged by the Brazilian competition authority since Telefónica and Telecom Italia, with Vivo and TIM respectively, are the two largest telephone companies competing in Brazil. In 2015, the company started a rebranding process towards the unified TIM brand, which would no longer be used only to identify mobile telephony offers but also for fixed telephony ones, abandoning the Telecom Italia brand. In the same year, the board of directors approved the new company's division, Infrastrutture Wireless Italiane (INWIT) which operates 11,500 wireless towers. It was revealed in October 2015 that shareholders Vivendi would raise their stakes further in the company from its current level of 15.49%. As of May 2017, Vivendi owns 24.6% of the company with Vivendi's CEO Arnaud de Puyfontaine becoming executive chairman of Telecom Italia. Amos Genish is the new CEO since 28 September 2017 and he has been criticized to have fired 4500 Telecom Italia employees in June 2018. He has been substituted by Luigi Gubitosi that became the new CEO on 18 November 2018. In 2016, following the rebranding that led to the adoption of the single TIM brand, the parent company also decided to change its identity. The company name of Telecom Italia S.p.A. it was in fact changed to TIM S.p.A., however still maintaining the previous name on some occasions. The main shareholders of TIM Group on 25 November 2022 are: Telecom Italia Mobile illegally charged money for Internet providing renew subscriptions for 5 years to its customers during the "free" subscription renewals. On 8 August 2012, TIM Brasil became involved in a massive scandal in Brazilian news after the release of report by the Brazilian National Telecommunications Agency Anatel. The report points that on TIM's prepaid voice plan (24.7% market share), called "Infinity" (in which the user pays roughly US$0.12 for each unlimited time call), the calls were intentionally dropped by the company, forcing the customers to make (and pay for) new calls to keep talking. In just one day, 8.1 million calls were dropped and the total profit was approximately $2 million. Upon release of the report, the Public Ministry of the Paraná State filed a lawsuit against TIM asking that it stop selling new mobile lines in Brasil and pay a multimillion-dollar fine for the damages against consumers. The Telecom Italia Group provides phone landline services and mobile services in Italy, GSM mobile phone services in Italy and Brazil through its TIM and TIM Brasil subsidiaries, and DSL Internet and telephony services in Italy and San Marino (through Telecom Italia San Marino). It also operates in international telecommunications services for other operators and corporations, through its subsidiary Telecom Italia Sparkle. In 2013, the total amount of the company's debt was about 26 billion €. Telecom Italia has 66,025 employees. Telecom Italia also controls Olivetti, a manufacturer of computer peripherals and mobile phones. On March 31, 2014, Telecom Italia led both the direct fixed access lines market with a 62% share, and the mobile postpaid segment with a 45% market share. In the mobile "prepaid" segment Telecom Italia owned a 31.5% market share together with Vodafone. After the merger of Wind and 3 Italy, approved on August 6, 2015, Telecom Italia is now the country's second largest carrier with 30 million customers, followed by Vodafone with 25 million customers. Telecom Italia has preserved its leadership on the direct fixed access lines market and the mobile postpaid segment. Telecom Italia S.p.A. deals with a total debt of 27 billion Euro as of the end of 2019. Moody rated the debt with a B1 grade negative outlook in 2015. In 2002, Telecom Italia subscribed to the United Nations corporate responsibility initiative Global Compact. It is also member of a number of stock market indexes which include companies focused on corporate social responsibility, including the Dow Jones Sustainability Indexes and those administered by FTSE Group's FTSE4Good. Its part-owned Brazilian subsidiary, TIM Brasil, is listed in the Bovespa's ISE (Índice de Sustentabilidade Empresarial) index. Telecom Italia promotes a sustainability strategy including both environmental and social issues: in June 2014 it signed an agreement with A2A to buy energy only from renewable sources. 1994-2003 2003-2016 2016-2019 2019- INWIT STET – Società Finanziaria Telefonica Telecom Italia Mobile Telecom Italia San Marino Telecom Italia Tower (Naples) TIM Brasil TIMvision "Salvatore Rossi - Presidente Telecom Italia | Gruppo TIM". texts.title: 1925–1964: STIPEL and early mandatory phone tax
texts.value: In 1925, the [[Italy|Italian]] [[Telephone network|phone network]] was reorganised by the [[Mussolini government|Benito Mussolini cabinet]] and the [[company]] [[STIPEL]] was established in the same year. The original core of Telecom Italia included four companies: [[TIMO]], [[TE.TI.]], [[TELVE]] and [[SET (company)|SET]]. Each of them operated in a specific geographical area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forumti.it/fti/downloads/Summary%20(in%20english).pdf?ref=search|title=Economics and politics of telecommunications}}</ref>

texts.title: 1964–1994: SIP
1994–2005: Telecom Italia, Telecom Italia Mobile and DSL services
texts.value:
Telecom Italia S.p.A. was officially created on 27 July 1994 by the [[merger]] of several [[Telecommunications company|telecommunications companies]] among which SIP, [[IRITEL]], [[Italcable]], [[Telespazio]] and [[SIRM]] (companies owned by [[STET – Società Finanziaria Telefonica|STET]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/corporate/about-us/history/80s-90s.html|title=Telecom Italia history on official site}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1994/marzo/18/nasce_Telecom_Italia_co_0_94031816349.shtml |title=nasce Telecom Italia |website=Corriere.it |language=it |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120803190924/http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1994/marzo/18/nasce_Telecom_Italia_co_0_94031816349.shtml |archive-date=2012-08-03}}</ref>
This was due to a reorganization plan for the [[Telecommunications industry|telecommunications sector]] presented by [[Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale|IRI]] to the Minister of Finance.

In 1995, the [[mobile telephony]] [[Division (business)|division]] was spun off as [[Telecom Italia Mobile]] (TIM), while Telecom Italia would take care of [[Fixed telephony|fixed]] and [[public telephony]] and [[Network infrastructure|network infrastructures]]. Interbusiness, Italy's largest [[Internet]] [[Telecommunications network|network]], was created and in the same period with [[Tin.it|Telecom Italia Net]] (Tin.it) and the first [[Internet Service Provider|ISPs]], [[Internet access]] became a reality in Italy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1995/febbraio/22/TELECOM_ITALIA_Interbusiness_con_Internet_co_8_9502221529.shtml|title=Archivio Corriere della Sera|website=archiviostorico.corriere.it}}</ref> In 1996, TIM introduced a new [[Rechargeable calling card|prepaid rechargeable phone card]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-q6GrtjFqYkC&pg=PA45|title=The economics of mobile telecommunications page 45 reference #50}}</ref> ([[GSM]]), and one year later launched [[Short Messaging Service|short messaging service]] (SMS) capability. In 1997, under the [[chairmanship]] of [[Guido Rossi (jurist)|Guido Rossi]], Telecom Italia was [[Privatization|privatised]] and was transformed into a large [[multimedia]] group.

By 2001, the company was in debt and was acquired by [[Marco Tronchetti Provera]]. The following year, the group released its [[DSL]] Flat service in Italy, [[Alice ADSL]], with a download speed of 32 kbit/s and an upload speed of 8 kbit/s for €40/month plus a monthly based tax of €14.57, the "Canone Telecom", besides the mandatory monthly [[Bill (payment)|bills]] for home [[Telephone number|telephone numbers]] (a home telephone number was required for [[ADSL]] service). [[Telecom Italia Media]], the group's multimedia company, was formed in 2003 from [[SEAT Pagine Gialle]], focussing its [[business]] on the [[Television industry|television sector]] with [[La7]] and [[MTV (Italy)|MTV]] [[Television channel|channels]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telecomitaliamedia.it/et/content/profile|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713155259/http://www.telecomitaliamedia.it/et/content/profile|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-07-13|title=Telecom Italia Media official site}}</ref>

After the reorganization of [[Publishing industry|editorial]] activities, in 2005 Telecom Italia acquired Tin.it and [[Virgilio.it|Virgilio]] from Telecom Italia Media.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivio-radiocor.ilsole24ore.com/articolo-433346/telecom-acquista-virgilio-tin-it/|title=News archive on IlSole24ore}}</ref>

The Telecom Italia Group also operates in [[South America]]; in [[Brazil]] as [[TIM Brasil]], and in [[Argentina]] and [[Paraguay]] with [[Telecom Argentina]]. TIM Brasil has its local [[headquarters]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnamericas.com/company-profile/en/tim-participacoes-sa-tim-participacoes?ref=search|title=TIM Participações S.A. (TIM Participações) - BNamericas}}</ref> Telecom Italia also had a 50% share in the [[Bolivia|Bolivian]] telecommunications company [[Entel (Bolivia)|Entel]] until its share was nationalised by the [[Bolivian government]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=217331&id_seccion=5 |title=Bolivia acepta arbitraje por nacionalización de una telefónica |publisher=El Comercio |date=August 27, 2008 |language=es |access-date=2010-04-13}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|date=2008-05-01|title=UPDATE 1-Bolivia announces takeover of Telecom Italia unit|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/entel-bolivia-idUSN0121819820080501|access-date=2020-09-17}}</ref>

texts.title: 2005–2014: Telecom Italia acquired by Telefónica
texts.value:
Telecom Italia reported mounting debts in 2005, and, one year later, [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] Marco Tronchetti Provera resigned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pirelli.com/mediaObject/corporate/documents/en/media/pirelli_telecom/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007/original/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007.pdf?ref=search|title=Pirelli as manager and investor in Telecom Italia (2001-2007)|access-date=24 August 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908100217/https://www.pirelli.com/mediaObject/corporate/documents/en/media/pirelli_telecom/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007/original/Pirelli_in_Telecom_Italia_2001_to_2007.pdf?ref=search|archive-date=8 September 2015|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

In 2007 the company was bought by Telco, a consortium of [[Telefónica]] and several [[Italian banks]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/29/technology/29cnd-telecom.html|title=Telefónica Gets Controlling Stake in Telecom Italia|first1=Victoria|last1=Burnett|first2=Peter|last2=Kiefer|newspaper=The New York Times |date=29 April 2007}}</ref> 
Telefónica owned 46% of Telco, the [[holding company]] that controlled 22% of Telecom Italia.

In late 2013, Telefónica announced its intention to acquire the entirety of Telco by January 2014, potentially becoming Telecom Italia's largest [[shareholder]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Mesco|first=Gabriele Lamonica And Manuela|date=2013-09-23|title=Telefónica in Talks to Become Majority Stakeholder in Telecom Italia's Holding Company|language=en-US|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702303759604579093060864026116.html|access-date=2021-04-02|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Emsden|first=Christopher|title=Telefonica to take control of Italy's Telco|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/telefonica-to-take-control-of-italys-telco-2013-09-24|access-date=2021-04-02|website=MarketWatch|language=en-US}}</ref> The plan, however, is being challenged by the Brazilian competition authority since Telefónica and Telecom Italia, with [[Vivo (telecommunications)|Vivo]] and TIM respectively, are the two largest telephone companies competing in Brazil.

texts.title: 2015–present: Rebrand
texts.value:
In 2015, the company started a [[rebranding]] process towards the unified TIM [[brand]], which would no longer be used only to identify mobile telephony offers but also for fixed telephony ones, abandoning the Telecom Italia brand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/economico-finanziario/2015/2015-2017-strategic-plan-approved.html|title=Telecom Italia Group: 2015–2017 strategic plan approved, cumulative investments planned totalling around 14.5 billion euros over the three year period|access-date=2015-04-02|work=Telecom Italia}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date= |title=Telecom Italia diventa TIM |url=http://in.tim.it/telecom-italia-diventa-tim/ |access-date=2015-08-13 |website=in.tim.it |language=it}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date= |title=Telecom Italia diventa TIM - La Nuova TIM |url=http://in.tim.it/la-nuova-tim/ |access-date=2015-08-13 |website=in.tim.it |language=it}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date= |title=Nuovo sito TIM Telecom italia |url=http://www.tim.it/nuovo-sito-TIM-Telecom-italia |access-date=2015-08-13 |website=www.tim.it |language=it}}</ref> In the same year, the [[board of directors]] approved the new company's division, [[Infrastrutture Wireless Italiane]] (INWIT) which operates 11,500 [[Cell site|wireless towers]].<ref>{{cite news
 |title=Telecom Italia gets OK for towers IPO, values it at €2.34B |url=http://seekingalpha.com/news/2564296-telecom-italia-gets-ok-for-towers-ipo-values-it-at-2_34b |date=5 June 2015 |work=Seeking Alpha |author=Aycock, Jason }}</ref><ref>{{cite news
 |title=Telecom Italia gets regulatory OK for €1bn towers IPO |author=Lennighan, Mary |date=5 June 2015 |work=Total Telecom |url=http://www.totaltele.com/view.aspx?ID=490171 }}</ref>

It was revealed in October 2015 that shareholders [[Vivendi]] would raise their stakes further in the company from its current level of 15.49%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Exclusive: Vivendi moves to raise Telecom Italia stake to around 19 percent - sources|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/01/us-telecomitalia-vivendi-exclusive-idUSKCN0RV5Q020151001|website=Reuters|date=1 October 2015|access-date=2 July 2017|archive-date=2 December 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181202064808/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-telecomitalia-vivendi-exclusive/exclusive-vivendi-moves-to-raise-telecom-italia-stake-to-around-19-percent-sources-idUSKCN0RV5Q020151001|url-status=dead}}</ref> As of May 2017, Vivendi owns 24.6% of the company with Vivendi's CEO [[Arnaud de Puyfontaine]] becoming [[executive chairman]] of Telecom Italia.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-telecomitalia-vivendi-chairman/telecom-italia-names-vivendi-ceo-de-puyfontaine-as-chairman-source-idUSKBN18S5LC|title=Telecom Italia appoints Vivendi's CEO as chairman|date=1 June 2017|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref> Amos Genish is the new CEO since 28 September 2017 and he has been criticized to have fired 4500 Telecom Italia employees in June 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.it/2018/05/17/tim-al-via-cassa-integrazione-per-3-4mila-persone_a_23436776/|title=Tim, scatta la cassa integrazione: in un anno gli esuberi arriveranno a 4.500|date=17 May 2018|website=L'HuffPost}}</ref> He has been substituted by Luigi Gubitosi that became the new CEO on 18 November 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.corriere.it/economia/18_novembre_18/chi-gubitosi-l-uomo-operazioni-difficili-4b4d6778-eb25-11e8-a3a7-d3b748828557.shtml|title=Chi è Gubitosi, l'uomo delle operazioni difficili|first=Redazione|last=Economia|date=18 November 2018|website=Corriere della Sera}}</ref>

In 2016, following the rebranding that led to the adoption of the single TIM brand, the [[parent company]] also decided to change its identity. The company name of Telecom Italia S.p.A. it was in fact changed to TIM S.p.A., however still maintaining the previous name on some occasions.<ref>{{Cite web |date= |title=Telecom Italia shareholders' meeting held: all items on the agenda approved {{!}} Telecom Italia Group |url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/economico-finanziario/2016/Telecom-Italia-shareholders-meeting-2016-05-25.html |access-date=2016-05-29 |website=www.telecomitalia.com}}</ref>

texts.title: Telecom Italia Mobile illegal charging money for "free" Internet providing renewals
texts.value: [[Telecom Italia Mobile]] illegally charged money for Internet providing renew subscriptions for 5 years to its customers during the "free" subscription renewals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.latecnosfera.com/2013/05/ecco-come-tim-frega-3-o-4-euro-ai-suoi.html|title=Ecco come Tim frega 4 euro al rinnovo delle promozioni - Tecnosfera|date=30 May 2013}}</ref>

texts.title: Fraud in Brazilian prepaid mobile lines
texts.value:
On 8 August 2012, [[TIM Brasil]] became involved in a massive scandal in Brazilian news after the release of report by the Brazilian National Telecommunications Agency Anatel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/parana/noticia/2012/08/tim-derruba-os-sinais-de-clientes-de-forma-proposital-aponta-relatorio.html |title=G1 – TIM derruba os sinais de clientes de forma proposital, aponta relatório – notícias em Paraná |date=7 August 2012 |publisher=G1.globo.com |access-date=2012-08-17}}</ref>

The report points that on TIM's prepaid voice plan (24.7% market share), called "Infinity" (in which the user pays roughly US$0.12 for each unlimited time call), the calls were intentionally dropped by the company, forcing the customers to make (and pay for) new calls to keep talking. In just one day, 8.1 million calls were dropped and the total profit was approximately $2 million. Upon release of the report, the Public Ministry of the Paraná State filed a lawsuit against TIM asking that it stop selling new mobile lines in Brasil and pay a multimillion-dollar fine for the damages against consumers.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://g1.globo.com/parana/noticia/2012/08/ministerio-publico-pede-suspensao-de-venda-de-chips-da-tim-no-parana.html |title= G1 – Ministério Público pede a suspensão de venda de chips da TIM no Paraná – notícias em Paraná |date= 6 August 2012 |publisher= G1.globo.com |access-date= 2012-08-17 }}</ref>

texts.title: Operations
texts.value:
The Telecom Italia Group provides phone landline services and mobile services in Italy, GSM mobile phone services in Italy and Brazil through its [[Telecom Italia Mobile|TIM]] and [[TIM Brasil]] [[Subsidiary|subsidiaries]], and [[DSL]] Internet and telephony services in Italy and [[San Marino]] (through [[Telecom Italia San Marino]]). It also operates in international [[Telecommunications service|telecommunications services]] for other operators and corporations, through its subsidiary [[Telecom Italia Sparkle]]. In 2013, the total amount of the company's debt was about 26 billion €.<ref name="ilfattoquotidiano.it">{{cite web|url=http://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2014/03/25/telecom-patuano-prepara-la-guerra-a-fossati-in-ballo-ce-uno-stipendio-da-1-milione/926469/|title=Telecom, Patuano prepara la guerra a Fossati. In ballo c'è uno stipendio da 1 milione - Il Fatto Quotidiano|author=Costanza Iotti|work=Il Fatto Quotidiano|date=25 March 2014 |access-date=2015-04-21}}</ref> Telecom Italia has 66,025 employees.

Telecom Italia also controls [[Olivetti]], a manufacturer of computer peripherals and mobile phones. On March 31, 2014, Telecom Italia led both the direct fixed access lines market with a 62% share, and the mobile [[postpaid]] segment with a 45% market share. In the mobile "[[prepaid mobile phone|prepaid]]" segment Telecom Italia owned a 31.5% market share together with [[Vodafone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agcom.it/documents/10179/1734740/Allegato+24-7-2014/d7ff11cd-3f3e-4742-b121-75f4e9ae8d34?version=1.0|title=Osservatorio Trimestrale sulle Telecomunicazioni |publisher=Agcom.it}}</ref>

After the merger of [[WIND (Italy)|Wind]] and [[3 Italy]], approved on August 6, 2015, Telecom Italia is now the country's second largest carrier with 30 million customers, followed by [[Vodafone Italy|Vodafone]] with 25 million customers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pyramidresearch.com/about-us/media-center/press-releases/the-merger-wind-3-italia-may-unlock-convergence-opportunities/?ref=search|title=Pyramid Research - The merger Wind-3 Italia may unlock convergence opportunities|website=www.pyramidresearch.com}}</ref> Telecom Italia has preserved its leadership on the direct fixed access lines market and the mobile postpaid segment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/finanza-e-mercati/2015-08-06/tlc-siglate-nozze-wind-e-3-italia-145750.shtml?uuid=ACn8Hwd?ref=search|title=Tlc, nozze tra Wind e 3 Italia. Fusione da 6,4 mld per il nuovo leader del mercato mobile}}</ref>

texts.title: High Debt Issue
texts.value: Telecom Italia S.p.A. deals with a total debt of 27 billion Euro as of the end of 2019.<ref name="auto"/> Moody rated the debt with a B1 grade negative outlook in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-assigns-Ba1-to-Telecom-Italias-Unsecured-Equity-Linked-Bonds--PR_321493|title=Moody's assigns Ba1 to Telecom Italia's Unsecured Equity-Linked Bonds; negative outlook|date=25 March 2015|website=Moodys.com}}</ref>

texts.title: Environmental practices and initiatives
texts.value:
In 2002, Telecom Italia subscribed to the [[United Nations]] [[Corporate social responsibility|corporate responsibility]] initiative [[The Global Compact|Global Compact]].<ref name="SR2009">{{cite journal |url=http://www.telecomitalia.it/content/dam/telecomitalia/en/archive/documents/sustainability/sustainability_reports/2009/Bilancio_sostenibilita_ENG_2009.pdf |title=Sustainability Report 2009 |access-date=27 July 2010 |journal=Telecom Italia |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705121258/http://www.telecomitalia.it/content/dam/telecomitalia/en/archive/documents/sustainability/sustainability_reports/2009/Bilancio_sostenibilita_ENG_2009.pdf |archive-date=5 July 2010}}</ref>
It is also member of a number of stock market indexes which include companies focused on corporate social responsibility, including the [[Dow Jones Sustainability Index]]es and those administered by [[FTSE Group]]'s [[FTSE4Good]]. Its part-owned Brazilian subsidiary, [[TIM Brasil]], is listed in the [[BM&F Bovespa|Bovespa]]'s ISE (Índice de Sustentabilidade Empresarial) index.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ri.tim.com.br/Show.aspx?IdMateria=2qNyWOWlMW4SUKaEph3e1Q== |title=Notice Bovespa ISE |access-date=29 April 2013 |work=TIM Participações S.A. |archive-url=https://archive.today/2013.06.16-004043/http://ri.tim.com.br/Show.aspx?IdMateria=2qNyWOWlMW4SUKaEph3e1Q== |archive-date=16 June 2013}}</ref>

Telecom Italia promotes a [[sustainability]] strategy including both environmental and social issues: in June 2014 it signed an agreement with [[A2A]] to buy energy only from [[renewable sources]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/istituzionale/2014/06-23.html?ref=search |title=Telecom Italia signs an agreement with A2A to buy energy only from renewable sources |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924114706/http://www.telecomitalia.com/tit/en/archivio/media/comunicati-stampa/telecom-italia/corporate/istituzionale/2014/06-23.html?ref=search |archive-date=24 September 2015 |date=23 June 2014 |access-date=16 May 2022 |work=Telecom Italia}}</ref>
